Review Text: A well written tale of a boy who manages to deal better with disability than those around him. His father is caught in the middle and doesn't actually know what the best to do for the boy is.
Review Title: A Boy Called Po
Rating: 4.0

reference_summary:
Life of Pi
Drama, Fantasy, Beautiful, Dreamlike
['After a cataclysmic shipwreck, young Pi Patel finds himself stranded on a lifeboat with only one other survivor – a ferocious Bengal tiger named Richard Parker. Bound by the need to survive, the two are cast on an epic journey.']

I found this series to be somewhat realistic and engaging, it had an excellent cast.
Season 1
{'Content advisory': ['Violence', 'alcohol use', 'smoking'], 'Audio languages': ['Português'], 'Subtitles': ['English [CC]'], 'Directors': ['Ciro Guerra'], 'Producers': ['Cristina Gallego'], 'Starring': ['Jan Bijvoet', 'Brionne Davis', 'Antonio Bolívar Salvador'], 'Studio': ['Oscilloscope']}
I felt that this was an excellent, well done portrayal of the past and present situations that exist in the Amazon. The cast was well suited for their roles and I was sympathetic with the situation they all found themselves in. The camera work was also top notch, everything woven together to create a really good film.
Embracing Embrace of the Serpent.
{'Content advisory': ['Violence', 'smoking', 'foul language', 'sexual content'], 'Audio languages': ['English Dialogue Boost: High', 'English', 'English Dialogue Boost: Medium'], 'Subtitles': ['English [CC]'], 'Directors': ['Todd Solondz'], 'Producers': ['David Distenfeld', 'Megan Ellison', 'David Hinojosa', 'Jillian Longnecker', 'Derrick Tseng', 'Christine Vachon'], 'Starring': ['Keaton Nigel Cooke', 'Tracy Letts', 'Julie Delpy'], 'Studio': ['Amazon Studios']}
Initially, I didn't know what to expect from this as I have never really had a very good relationship with a dachshund, but the one in this movie impressed me. To see the effects of this dog wandering around from person to person was somewhat revealing and to see the heartbreaking things that the dog had to endure was definitely a clue that this was not a Disney movie. The ending was a bit macabre, but made sense in the context of the movie.
Wiener-Dog Daze
{'Audio languages': ['English'], 'Subtitles': ['English [CC]'], 'Directors': ['George Clooney'], 'Producers': ['George Clooney', 'Marion Kodama Yue'], 'Starring': ['David Strathairn', 'Patricia Clarkson', 'George Clooney']}
I felt this was an excellent portrayal of the events surrounding the McCarthy era.
Goodnight, and Good Luck
Straight Men and the Men Who Love Them 3
Drama, International, LGBTQ
['This third installment of international shorts chronicles the pitfalls and pleasures of fluid sexuality in men exposing the complex, dynamic and at times volatile relationships and situations surrounding friendships and hidden attractions. Shorts include: "Quarters", "Rubber Duckie", "Boy Game", "Early One Summer", "From Here There".']
{'Subtitles': ['None available'], 'Directors': ['Jorge Ameer', 'Henry Alberto', 'Anna Österlund Nolskog', 'Gary Thomas', 'Yee Lam Wong'], 'Starring': ['Robert Brinkley', 'Tom Drexel', 'Max Hambleton']}
Definitely lacking in substance, it starts out pretty lame and starts to get tolerable as it goes on. Not worth the time.
Straight Men...
{'Audio languages': ['Dansk'], 'Subtitles': ['English [CC]'], 'Directors': ['Bille August'], 'Producers': ['Per Holst'], 'Starring': ['Pelle Hvenegaard', 'Max von Sydow'], 'Studio': ['Film Movement']}
A very thoughtful story about the way people are connected (or not connected depending on your point of view) and how honesty and perseverance can sometimes triumph.
Pelle the Conqueror

profile:
**User Summary:**

The user demonstrates a profound appreciation for dramatic and fantasy films with visually striking qualities, alongside a strong interest in well-produced documentaries. Their preferences lean toward thought-provoking narratives, survival stories, and films that offer profound life lessons, highlighting an affinity for educational content that provides insightful perspectives.

Recent engagement reveals an ongoing interest in character-driven stories that explore themes of human connection and the challenges of living with disability. This indicates a deep empathy toward characters and their situations, reinforcing their tendency to favor narratives that address real-world issues and social challenges. Their viewing style remains engaged, as they seek films that evoke deep reflection and emotional responses, underlining their commitment to storytelling with substance.

Social recommendations play a crucial role in their film selection, reflecting a strong trust in peer opinions and a consistent pattern of generally favorable ratings, tempered by discernment. The user prioritizes quality storytelling and narrative strength, reinforcing their desire for films that prompt introspection and emotional engagement. Their recent critique underscores an appreciation for well-written tales that explore the complexities of human relationships and personal growth, further solidifying their preference for narratives that enrich their understanding of diverse experiences.
